discussion.content:
if we choose “A. Messages are stored external to the device.”
as one of the correct answers then we have to choose “D. Messages can be erased when the device reboots.”
because we are talking about an external syslog server.
and if we choose “C. Syslog logging is disabled by default.” we have to choose “E. Messages are stored in the internal memory of the device.” because we are talking here about a local syslog.

http://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=426638&seqNum=3
Reading above article, I go with CE

questions.question_text: Which two statements about syslog logging are true? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Messages can be erased when the device reboots.
choices.A: The size of the log is dependent on the resources of the device.
choices.C: Messages are stored external to the device.
choices.E: Syslog logging is disabled by default.
choices.D: Messages are stored in the internal memory of the device.

questions.question_text: What are three characteristics of the TCP protocol? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCF
B.c.a is correct

comments.content: I guess because it dosent happens on the application layer, it happens on the tcp transport layer

choices.B: The connection is established before data is transmitted.
choices.F: It uses separate SYN and ACK messages to establish a connection.
choices.C: It ensures that all data is transmitted and received by the remote device.
choices.D: It supports significantly higher transmission speeds than UDP.
choices.E: It requires applications to determine when data packets must be retransmitted.
choices.A: It uses a single SYN-ACK message to establish a connection.

questions.answer_description: Relevant parts of the config shown below:
questions.question_text:
Instructions:
- Enter IOS commands on the device to verify network operation and answer the multiple questions.
- THIS TASK DOES NOT REQUIRE REVICE CONFIGURATION.
- Click the device icon to gain access to the console device of the router. No console or enable passwords are required.
- To access the multiple-choice questions, click the numbered boxes on the left of the top panel.
- there are four multiple-choice questions with this task. Be sure to answer all four questions before clicking Next button.
Scenario:
//IMG//

Refer to the topology. Your company has connected the routers R1, R2, and R3 with serial links. R2 and R3 are connected to the switches SW1 and SW2, respectively. SW1 and SW2 are also connected to the routers R4 and R5.
The EIGRP routing protocol is configured.
You are required to troubleshoot and resolve the EIGRP issues between the various routers.
Use the appropriate show commands to troubleshoot the issues.
The loopback interfaces on R4 with the IP addresses of 10.4.4.4/32, 10.4.4.5/32 and 10.4.4.6/32 are not appearing in the routing table of R5.
Why are the interfaces missing?

choices.B: R4 has been incorrectly configured to be in another AS, so it does not peer with R5.
choices.A: The interfaces are shutdown, so they are not being advertised.
choices.C: Automatic summarization is enabled, so only the 10.0.0.0 network is displayed.
choices.D: The loopback addresses haven’t been advertised, and the network command is missing on R4.

discussion.content: Can something be done to show the running-config of R4 and R5 In full? At the moment it is being chopped off

choices.D: The R3 router ID is configured on R4.
choices.B: There is a Layer 2 issue; an encapsulation mismatch on serial links.
choices.C: There is an OSPF hello and dead interval mismatch.
choices.A: There is an area ID mismatch.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A

questions.question_text: Which two options describe benefits of aggregated chassis technology? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Benefits of Switch Stacking & Chassis Aggregation
+ The stack would have a single management IP address.
+ The engineer would connect with Telnet or SSH to one switch (with that one management IP address), not multiple switches.
+ One configuration file would include all interfaces in all physical switches.
+ STP, CDP, VTP would run on one switch, not multiple switches.
+ The switch ports would appear as if all are on the same switch.
+ There would be one MAC address table, and it would reference all ports on all physical switches.

choices.F: Switches can be located anywhere regardless of their physical distance from one another.
choices.C: It requires only three IP addresses per VLAN.
choices.D: It requires only one IP address per VLAN.
choices.E: It supports HSRP, VRRP, and GLBP.
